metadata.value: Photographs of the Elliot Marbles; and other subjects; in the Central Museum Madras
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: Left: Close view of drum slab also shown on p. 27. The drum slab depicts the four events related to the Buddha's birth: Māyādevī's Dream (top right); the Interpretation of the Dream attended by the dīkpāla-s (top left); the Birth of the Buddha attended again by the dīkpāla-s (bottom right); the Presentation of the Buddha to the caitya of the Śākyas (bottom left) (Elliot no. 122). Right: Railing pillar with lotus medallions, decorative and narrative reliefs. The upper section is lost. The inner face depicts one full and one half-lotus as well as the Elevation of the Bodhisattva's Turban in the upper fluted area and the Elevation of the Begging Bowl in the lower fluted area, with both events surrounded by flying devas or gods. (Elliot no. 130).
metadata.label: Description

metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: Drum slab carved with a stupa attended by several figures, with naga (snake) females and naga kings inside the gateway worshipping relics of the Buddha; the drum of the stupa is carved with dharmacakras (wheels of the law), stupas and possibly the Enlightenment. The drum frieze panels and dome slabs are carved with a stories from the life of the Buddha: the Enlightenment, the First Sermon, Sarvamdadavadana, Suruci Jataka, nagas, Monkey's offering (Elliot no. 116).
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Photographs of the Elliot Marbles; and other subjects; in the Central Museum Madras
metadata.label: Title

metadata.value: In the centre of this photograph is a drum-frieze containing three narrative registers; the first depicts the Sibi jataka, the second the Buddha subdues the elephant Nalagiri and the last, the Sasa Jataka (Elliot no. 105). Above this sits a fragment of a dome slab divided into two registers. In the lower register is Nagaraja and his 4 queens (only their naga headdresses remain intact) - in the upper register is the Cakravartin (Universal Monarch) surrounded by female and male figures and with a horse. A frieze of seated Buddhas separates the two registers (Elliot no. 129). Flanking these two fragments are two pilasters carved in high relief. The pilaster of the left is crowned with a stupa in front of a dharmacakra, adorned with narrative reliefs in four registers, from the bottom: Prince Siddhartha taking leave of Candaka and his horse, The Bodhisattva seated on a throne in abhayamudra, the Buddha seated under a torana and a stupa with a Buddha in abhaya mudra seated in the gateway (Elliot no. 16). The pilaster on the right is adorned with narrative reliefs (from the bottom): a standing princely figure, a seated Bodhisattva with worshippers, and a stupa with a Buddha in abhayamudra seated in the gateway (Elliot no. 15).
metadata.label: Description
